hints_html: Write the system of equations as an extended matrix - it should look familiar! How can you use previous work to determine the solution of the corresponding system of equations?
hints_latex:
Write the system of equations as an extended matrix - it should look
familiar! How can you use previous work to determine the solution of the
corresponding system of equations?
hints_raw: Write the system of equations as an extended matrix - it should look familiar!  How can you use previous work to determine the solution of the corresponding system of equations?
question: 2 (d)
sols_html:
If we write the system of equations as an extended matrix, it will be exactly the matrix A. Thus, thinking of A as an extended matrix, we know it represents 4 equations in 4 variables. Row operations lead to an equivalent system of equations, with the same solutions. Hence we can instead choose the extended matrix B, even better, we can further use the reduced matrix we used in part (b), i.e. the matrix:

\(\left[ \begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 0 & 7 & 0 & -39 \\ 0 & 1 & -3 & 0 & 31 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & -7 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right]\)

to determine the answer. From the above matrix, we can read the equations:

\[\begin{aligned} &x + 7z &= -39\\ &y -3z &= 31\\ &w &= -7\end{aligned}\]

From this, we can quickly see that \(w = 0\) leads to no solution (i.e. it would lead to saying 0 = -7).

If z=0, then we get the solution

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x = -39, \quad y = 31,\quad w = -7\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
If we write the system of equations as an extended matrix, it will be
exactly the matrix \emph{A}. Thus, thinking of \emph{A} as an extended
matrix, we know it represents 4 equations in 4 variables. Row operations
lead to an equivalent system of equations, with the same solutions.
Hence we can instead choose the extended matrix \emph{B}, even better,
we can further use the reduced matrix we used in
{part
(b)}, i.e. the matrix:

$\left[ \begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & 7 & 0 & -39 \\ 
0 & 1 & -3 & 0 & 31 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & -7 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array} \right]$

to determine the answer. From the above matrix, we can read the
equations:

\begin{align*}
&x + 7z &= -39\\
&y -3z &= 31\\
&w &= -7
\end{align*}

From this, we can quickly see that $w = 0$ leads to no solution (i.e. it
would lead to saying \emph{0 = -7}).

If \emph{z=0}, then we get the solution

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle x = -39, \quad y = 31,\quad w = -7
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
If we write the system of equations as an extended matrix, it will be exactly the matrix ''A''.  Thus, thinking of ''A'' as an extended matrix, we know it represents 4 equations in 4 variables.  Row operations lead to an equivalent system of equations, with the same solutions. Hence we can instead choose the extended matrix ''B'', even better, we can further use the reduced matrix we used in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH221/April_2013/Question_02_(b)|part (b)]], i.e. the matrix:

<math> \left[ \begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & 7 & 0 & -39 \\ 
0 & 1 & -3 & 0 & 31 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & -7 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array} \right] </math> 

to determine the answer. From the above matrix, we can read the equations:

<math> 
\begin{align}
&x + 7z &= -39\\
&y -3z &= 31\\
&w &= -7
\end{align} 
</math> 

From this, we can quickly see that <math> w = 0</math> leads to no solution (i.e. it would lead to saying ''0 = -7'').

If ''z=0'', then we get the solution
:<math> \displaystyle x = -39, \quad y = 31,\quad w = -7</math>
statement_html:
Let

\(A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 2 & 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 & 9 & 0 & 7 \\ 2 & 3 & 5 & 1 & 8 \\ 2 & 2 & 8 & -3 & 5 \end{array} \right] B = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 2 & 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & -3 & 5 & -4 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & -7 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right]\)

The matrices A and B are related by \(B = MA\) , where M is an invertible 4x4 matrix.

d) Find the general solution of the system of equations:

\[\begin{aligned} &x +2y +z + 3w &= 2\\ &3x + 4y + 9z &= 7\\ &2x + 3y + 5z + w &= 8\\ &2x + 2y + 8z - 3w &= 5\end{aligned}\]

Is there a solution in which \(z = 0\)? If so, find it. Is there a solution in which \(w = 0\)? If so, find it.
statement_latex:
Let

$A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 2 & 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 
3 & 4 & 9 & 0 & 7 \\ 
2 & 3 & 5 & 1 & 8 \\ 
2 & 2 & 8 & -3 & 5
\end{array} \right]  B = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 2 & 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -3 & 5 & -4 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & -7 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array} \right]$

The matrices \emph{A} and \emph{B} are related by $B = MA$ , where
\emph{M} is an invertible 4x4 matrix.

d) Find the general solution of the system of equations:

\begin{align*}
&x +2y +z + 3w &= 2\\
&3x + 4y + 9z  &= 7\\
&2x + 3y + 5z + w &= 8\\
&2x + 2y + 8z - 3w &= 5
\end{align*}

Is there a solution in which $z = 0$? If so, find it. Is there a
solution in which $w = 0$? If so, find it.
statement_raw:
Let

<math> A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 2 & 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 
3 & 4 & 9 & 0 & 7 \\ 
2 & 3 & 5 & 1 & 8 \\ 
2 & 2 & 8 & -3 & 5
\end{array} \right]  B = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 2 & 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -3 & 5 & -4 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & -7 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array} \right] </math> 

The matrices ''A'' and ''B'' are related by <math> B = MA</math> , where ''M'' is an invertible 4x4 matrix.

d) Find the general solution of the system of equations:

<math> 
\begin{align}
&x +2y +z + 3w &= 2\\
&3x + 4y + 9z  &= 7\\
&2x + 3y + 5z + w &= 8\\
&2x + 2y + 8z - 3w &= 5
\end{align} 
</math> 

Is there a solution in which <math> z = 0</math>? If so, find it. Is there a solution in which <math> w = 0</math>? If so, find it.
